quiz.title: Unit 5: Energy & Power (Quiz 5)
quiz.subtitle: Comprehensive Energy Fundamentals (50 Questions)
quiz.subject: Physics
quiz.topic: Work, Energy Types, Conservation, Power, and Machines

questions.question: What is the scientific definition of work?
options: Any physical activity that causes tiredness
Force applied over a distance in the direction of force
The amount of energy an object contains
questions.explanation: Work is quantitatively defined as force applied through a distance in the direction of the force: W = F × d × cosθ.

questions.question: A 15 N force pushes a box 8 meters horizontally. How much work is done?
questions.explanation: Work = Force × distance = 15 N × 8 m = 120 J

questions.question: Which scenario demonstrates NO work being done according to physics?
options: Lifting a book from floor to desk
Pulling a wagon across a park
questions.explanation: No work is done when there is no displacement, even if considerable force is applied.

questions.question: What is the kinetic energy of a 4 kg object moving at 5 m/s?
questions.explanation: KE = ½mv² = ½ × 4 kg × (5 m/s)² = 2 × 25 = 50 J

questions.question: How does kinetic energy change when velocity triples?
questions.explanation: KE depends on v², so tripling velocity increases kinetic energy by 3² = 9 times.

questions.question: A 8 kg object has 144 J of kinetic energy. What is its speed?
questions.explanation: KE = ½mv² → 144 = ½ × 8 × v² → v² = 36 → v = 6 m/s

questions.question: What type of energy is stored in a compressed spring?
questions.explanation: Compressed or stretched springs store elastic potential energy.

questions.question: What is the gravitational potential energy of a 5 kg object 6 meters above the ground?
questions.explanation: GPE = mgh = 5 kg × 9.8 m/s² × 6 m = 294 J

questions.question: When does a pendulum have maximum gravitational potential energy?
options: At the lowest point of swing
At the highest points of swing
questions.explanation: GPE increases with height, so maximum at the highest points of the swing.

questions.question: A construction worker lifts a 50 N box 3 m vertically. How much work did they do against gravity?
questions.explanation: Work against gravity = weight × height = 50 N × 3 m = 150 J

questions.question: Which has more kinetic energy: a 1500 kg car at 20 m/s or a 3000 kg truck at 10 m/s?
questions.explanation: Car: ½×1500×400 = 300,000 J; Truck: ½×3000×100 = 150,000 J; Car has more kinetic energy.

questions.question: What happens to work done when force is applied perpendicular to displacement?
questions.explanation: Work = Fd cosθ; when θ = 90°, cos90° = 0, so work = 0.

questions.question: What does the Law of Conservation of Energy state?
options: Energy can be created but not destroyed
Energy can be destroyed but not created
Energy cannot be created or destroyed
Total energy in the universe is decreasing
questions.explanation: Energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed from one form to another or transferred between objects.

questions.question: A 3 kg ball is dropped from 20 m height. What is its speed just before hitting the ground?
questions.explanation: Using conservation: mgh = ½mv² → v = √(2gh) = √(2×9.8×20) = √392 = 19.8 ≈ 20 m/s

questions.question: What energy transformation occurs when a bowstring is released?
questions.explanation: Elastic potential energy in the stretched bowstring converts to kinetic energy of the arrow.

questions.question: The Work-Energy Theorem states that net work done equals:
questions.explanation: Net work done on an object equals its change in kinetic energy: W_net = ΔKE

questions.question: A 500 N force accelerates a 40 kg object from 3 m/s to 9 m/s. How much work is done?
What is power defined as in physics?
questions.explanation: Power is the rate of doing work or transferring energy: P = Work/time

questions.question: A machine does 2400 J of work in 8 seconds. What is its power output?
questions.explanation: Power = Work/time = 2400 J / 8 s = 300 W

questions.question: A child on a swing reaches maximum speed:
questions.explanation: Kinetic energy and speed are maximum at the lowest point where gravitational potential energy is minimum.

questions.question: A 70 kg athlete runs up 5 m of stairs in 7 seconds. What power is developed?
In an ideal frictionless system, a roller coaster car starting at height h can reach:
options: Slightly less than h due to air resistance
Much higher than h with enough speed
questions.explanation: With no energy losses to friction or air resistance, conservation of energy allows reaching exactly the same height.

questions.question: Which quantity has units of joules per second?
questions.explanation: Power is measured in watts, and 1 watt = 1 joule/second.

questions.question: A motor produces 25,000 W of power. How much work can it do in 20 seconds?
questions.explanation: Work = Power × time = 25,000 W × 20 s = 500,000 J

questions.question: A 2 kg object slides down a frictionless ramp from 12 m height. What is its speed at the bottom?
What is the main purpose of a simple machine?
options: To multiply force or change direction of force
To reduce the total work needed
To increase energy efficiency to over 100%
questions.explanation: Simple machines multiply force or change its direction, but cannot reduce the total work required due to conservation of energy.

questions.question: Which simple machine consists of a wheel with a grooved rim and a rope?
questions.explanation: A pulley is a wheel with a grooved rim designed for a rope or cable to run along the groove.

questions.question: What is mechanical advantage (MA) defined as?
questions.explanation: Mechanical Advantage = Output force / Input force

questions.question: A lever requires 40 N input to lift 160 N load. What is its mechanical advantage?
questions.explanation: MA = Output force / Input force = 160 N / 40 N = 4

questions.question: What is the ideal mechanical advantage of a ramp 6 m long and 2 m high?
questions.explanation: IMA of inclined plane = length / height = 6 m / 2 m = 3

questions.question: Which class of lever has the fulcrum between the input force and output force?
questions.explanation: First class lever has the fulcrum between the input force (effort) and output force (load).

questions.question: A wheelbarrow is an example of which class of lever?
questions.explanation: Wheelbarrow is a second class lever with the load between the fulcrum (wheel) and effort (handles).

questions.question: What is efficiency defined as?
questions.explanation: Efficiency = (Useful output work / Total input work) × 100%

questions.question: A machine has 80% efficiency. If 500 J of work is input, how much useful work is output?
questions.explanation: Useful output work = Efficiency × Input work = 0.80 × 500 J = 400 J

questions.question: Why can no machine be 100% efficient?
options: It would violate conservation of energy
Friction and other energy losses always occur
Input work is always less than output work
questions.explanation: Friction, air resistance, sound, and heat always cause some energy loss in real machines.

questions.question: What is the mechanical advantage of a single fixed pulley?
questions.explanation: A single fixed pulley has MA = 1; it changes direction but doesn't multiply force.

questions.question: A system of 4 pulleys (block and tackle) has ideal mechanical advantage:
questions.explanation: In a block and tackle system, ideal MA equals the number of rope segments supporting the load.

questions.question: A screw is essentially a modified version of which simple machine?
questions.explanation: A screw is an inclined plane wrapped around a cylinder.

questions.question: What is the relationship between work input and work output in an ideal machine?
questions.explanation: In an ideal machine (100% efficient), work input equals work output due to conservation of energy.

questions.question: A human arm lifting a weight is an example of which class of lever?
questions.explanation: The arm is a third class lever with the effort (muscle) between the fulcrum (elbow) and load (hand).

questions.question: What is the unit of power in the SI system?
questions.explanation: The watt (W) is the SI unit of power, named after James Watt.

questions.question: A 60 W light bulb is left on for 5 hours. How much energy does it use?
What is the gravitational potential energy of a 1 kg object at 10 m height on the Moon (g = 1.6 m/s²)?
questions.explanation: GPE = mgh = 1 kg × 1.6 m/s² × 10 m = 16 J

questions.question: Which has greater kinetic energy: a 0.01 kg bullet at 1000 m/s or a 1000 kg car at 1 m/s?
questions.explanation: Bullet: ½×0.01×1,000,000 = 5,000 J; Car: ½×1000×1 = 500 J; Bullet has more kinetic energy.

questions.question: What is the efficiency of a machine that requires 800 J input to do 600 J of useful work?
questions.explanation: Efficiency = (Useful output / Input) × 100% = (600 J / 800 J) × 100% = 75%

questions.question: A spring with k = 200 N/m is compressed 0.1 m. What elastic potential energy is stored?
questions.explanation: Elastic PE = ½kx² = ½ × 200 N/m × (0.1 m)² = 100 × 0.01 = 1 J

questions.question: What is the power output of a pump that lifts 1000 kg of water 10 m in 20 seconds?
A machine has mechanical advantage 5 and efficiency 80%. If output force is 400 N, what input force is needed?
questions.explanation: Ideal input force = Output force / MA = 400 N / 5 = 80 N; Actual input force = 80 N / 0.8 = 100 N

questions.question: What is the main energy transformation in a hydroelectric dam?
questions.explanation: Water's gravitational potential energy converts to kinetic energy, then to electrical energy via turbines.

questions.question: A 0.2 kg baseball is thrown at 30 m/s. What is its kinetic energy?

scoreMessages.50: Good foundation! Focus on work-energy theorem and conservation of energy applications.
